Centering activity - Setting the stage - Paired coding - Group Debrief ## Centering Activity * Reena :-) ## Exit Ticket Results {.smaller} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](06-assess_braceros_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: # Setting the Stage - This week's focus is on data tidying and transformation - Using metadata from 90 interviews in the Bracero Archive that I scraped - Important to note that each row represents a person, a life, and a family impacted by the Bracero Program ## Learning Outcomes - Understand data structure - Transform and tidy data for necessary questions - Explore and summarize patterns - Connect your findings to theoretical understandings of procedural justice ## Let's get Started - Find your pair - Open Posit ## First Steps - Import Data - Load packages - You may need to install readxl using `install.packages("package name")`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(readxl) # for loading data library(tidyverse) # for tidying ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ## Load Data ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero <- read_excel("data/bracero_pull.xlsx") ``` ::: ## Our data {.smaller} - 90 rows (interviews) - 6 variables (all `chr` type) - title = Person interviewed - subject = topic of interview - description = summary of interview - date = date of interview - identifier = link to original interview file - language = language interview was conducted in ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} glimpse(bracero) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 90 Columns: 6 $ title "Richard Hancock", "Pedro Cantor", "Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n", "‚Ä¶ $ subject "Do√±a Ana County Farm Bureau", "Bracero", "Bracero", "Brac‚Ä¶ $ description "Biographical Synopsis of Interviewee: Richard Hancock wa‚Ä¶ $ date "2003-04-21", "2005-07-27", "2006-05-22", "2005-09-01", "2‚Ä¶ $ identifier "https://braceroarchive.org/items/show/82;https://braceroa‚Ä¶ $ language "eng", "spa", "spa", "spa", "eng", "spa", "spa", "eng", "s‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: ## Variable Types {.smaller} We will work primarily with five types of variables in this course: - `chr` is character - `dbl` is double (number) - `int` is an integer - `date` is date - `fct` is factor Thoughts on what variables we may want to change the data types of? ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 90 Columns: 6 $ title "Richard Hancock", "Pedro Cantor", "Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n", "‚Ä¶ $ subject "Do√±a Ana County Farm Bureau", "Bracero", "Bracero", "Brac‚Ä¶ $ description "Biographical Synopsis of Interviewee: Richard Hancock wa‚Ä¶ $ date "2003-04-21", "2005-07-27", "2006-05-22", "2005-09-01", "2‚Ä¶ $ identifier "https://braceroarchive.org/items/show/82;https://braceroa‚Ä¶ $ language "eng", "spa", "spa", "spa", "eng", "spa", "spa", "eng", "s‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: # Transforming Data (Columns) {.smaller} - Four functions can change the *columns* of your data without affecting your *rows* - mutate(): creates new columns based on existing ones - select(): chooses what columns you want in your dataframe - rename(): changes the names of current columns - relocate(): changes the position of those columns ## mutate() function {.smaller} - mutate() creates new columns based on existing ones - We use the `mutate()` function to create a new column `date_format`, using the `as.Date()` function to change the original `date` column's data type. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero |> mutate(date_format = as.Date(date)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 90 √ó 7 title subject description date identifier language date_format 1 Richard Hancock Do√±a A‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 2003-04-21 2 Pedro Cantor Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-27 3 Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2006‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2006-05-22 4 Vincente Delgado Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005-09-01 5 Inez Rios Intera‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 2003-01-31 6 Manuel Enriquez Sa‚Ä¶ Bureau‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2003-02-06 7 Alberto Montes Gon‚Ä¶ Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-27 8 Ernesto Espino Son of‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 2005-11-12 9 Jes√∫s Ort√≠z Torres Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005-08-31 10 Jos√© G. Corral Son of‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005-11-12 # ‚Ñπ 80 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## mutate() function (cont.) {.smaller} - We can also pair it with additional functions, such as ifelse statements. - `%in%c()` allows you to list multiple matches in the `subject` column. ![](images/ifelse.png) ## select() function {.smaller} - `select()` can be used to select or deselect columns. - Perhaps we'd like to remove the original `date` column from our dataframe. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|3|7|11"} # select column you don't want bracero |> select(-date) # select columns you do want bracero |> select(title, subject, description, date, identifier, language, date_format) # select columns in a row, except the column you don't want bracero |> select(title:description, identifier:date_format) ``` ::: ## rename() function {.smaller} - `rename()` changes the names of current columns - let's rename `title` to something more descriptive like `interviewee`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero |> rename("interviewee" = "title") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 90 √ó 6 interviewee subject description date identifier language 1 Richard Hancock Do√±a Ana Coun‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 2 Pedro Cantor Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 3 Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2006‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 4 Vincente Delgado Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 5 Inez Rios Interaction w‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 6 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau of Emp‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 7 Alberto Montes Gonz√°lez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 8 Ernesto Espino Son of bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 9 Jes√∫s Ort√≠z Torres Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 10 Jos√© G. Corral Son of a brac‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa # ‚Ñπ 80 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## relocate() function {.smaller} - `relocate()` changes the position of columns - `relocate()` automatically puts the column at the front, so you have to specify the column's location, and `.after` or `.before`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero |> relocate(identifier, .after = language) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 90 √ó 6 title subject description date language identifier 1 Richard Hancock Do√±a Ana Coun‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ eng https://b‚Ä¶ 2 Pedro Cantor Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 3 Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2006‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 4 Vincente Delgado Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 5 Inez Rios Interaction w‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ eng https://b‚Ä¶ 6 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau of Emp‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 7 Alberto Montes Gonz√°lez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 8 Ernesto Espino Son of bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ eng https://b‚Ä¶ 9 Jes√∫s Ort√≠z Torres Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 10 Jos√© G. Corral Son of a brac‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ # ‚Ñπ 80 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## Put it together {.smaller} - We can put all of these data transformation actions together using the `|>` function - line 1: creates new dataframe called `bracero_clean` - line 2: creates formatted date column called `date_format` from the original `date` column. - line 3: selects for all columns *except* for the old `date` column - line 4: renames the `title` column to `interviewee` - line 5: moves the `indentifier` column to after the `date_format` column. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="1|2|3|4|5"} bracero_clean <- bracero |> mutate(date_format = as.Date(date)) |> select(-date) |> rename("interviewee" = "title") |> relocate(identifier, .after = date_format) ``` ::: # Exercise One {.smaller} - Starting with the `bracero` dataframe, code the following three actions using |> into a new dataframe called `bracero_ex1`: - mutate the `date` column into a new column, called `date_format`. Change the data type from character to 'year-month-date'. - hint: you may need to type `?as.Date()` into the console for help. - select the `title`, `date_format`, and `description` columns. - relocate the `date_format` column to be the first in the dataframe. # Transforming Data (Rows) - Moving on to rows! - `filter()` is a function that allows you to keep rows of interest (but won't change the order of your rows) - `arrange()` changes the order of your rows (but won't filter for anything) ## filter() function {.smaller} - Use the `filter()` function to select rows that correspond to values of interest. - use `==` to filter the `language` column for rows with a direct match (in this case `spa`) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> filter(language == "spa") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 75 √ó 6 interviewee subject description language date_format identifier 1 Pedro Cantor Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-27 https://b‚Ä¶ 2 Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2006-05-22 https://b‚Ä¶ 3 Vincente Delgado Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-09-01 https://b‚Ä¶ 4 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau ‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2003-02-06 https://b‚Ä¶ 5 Alberto Montes Gonz√°lez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-27 https://b‚Ä¶ 6 Jes√∫s Ort√≠z Torres Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-08-31 https://b‚Ä¶ 7 Jos√© G. Corral Son of ‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-11-12 https://b‚Ä¶ 8 Eduardo De Santiago Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2003-03-03 https://b‚Ä¶ 9 Salvador Torres Beltr√°n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2006-05-22 https://b‚Ä¶ 10 Luis Zamudio Villagomez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-27 https://b‚Ä¶ # ‚Ñπ 65 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## filter() operations {.smaller} - `>` greater than - `>=` greater than or equal to - `<` less than - `<=` less than or equal to - `==` equal to - `!=` does not equal - Can use `&` to combine conditions (and) - `|` to select multiple conditions (or) - Perhaps we're interested in interviews that took place after 2004 AND are in English: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> filter(date_format >= 2004-01-01 & language == "eng") ``` ::: ## filter() and str_detect() {.smaller} - We can also combine filter with the `str_detect()` function, to look for character matches in a column (in this case the `interviewee` column, with any matches including `Alberto` . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> filter(str_detect(interviewee, "Alberto")) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 √ó 6 interviewee subject description language date_format identifier 1 Alberto Montes Gonz√°lez Bracero "Biographica‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-27 https://b‚Ä¶ 2 Alberto Magall√≥n Jim√©nez Bracero "Biographica‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-28 https://b‚Ä¶ 3 Alberto Mendoza Torres bracero "Biographica‚Ä¶ spa 2003-09-26 https://b‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: ## arrange() - `arrange()` sorts your rows based on the values in the columns. - If you sort more than one row, it will sort the first variable, and the others will be used to "break ties" - including `desc()` will sort your column values big to small. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> arrange(date_format, interviewee) ``` ::: ## Exercise Two {.smaller} 1. Filter the `bracero_clean` dataframe for any interviews that took place before 2005 and with an interviewee whose name includes "Guadalupe". 2. Arrange the `bracero_clean` data frame in descending order by `date_format`. What was the date, how many interviews took place on that date, and who is listed first? 3. Filter the `bracero_clean` dataframe for any description columns that mention "California". How many interviewees are there? # Grouping Data ## group_by() function {.smaller} - `group_by()` function is really helpful for sorting your data into groups for analysis. - `group_by()` function does not change your data, but *will change* subsequent operations if you use them in tandem with a `group_by()` - You can also group by multiple columns. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> group_by(language) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 90 √ó 6 # Groups: language [2] interviewee subject description language date_format identifier 1 Richard Hancock Do√±a An‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2003-04-21 https://b‚Ä¶ 2 Pedro Cantor Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-27 https://b‚Ä¶ 3 Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2006-05-22 https://b‚Ä¶ 4 Vincente Delgado Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-09-01 https://b‚Ä¶ 5 Inez Rios Interac‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2003-01-31 https://b‚Ä¶ 6 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau ‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2003-02-06 https://b‚Ä¶ 7 Alberto Montes Gonz√°lez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-27 https://b‚Ä¶ 8 Ernesto Espino Son of ‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2005-11-12 https://b‚Ä¶ 9 Jes√∫s Ort√≠z Torres Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-08-31 https://b‚Ä¶ 10 Jos√© G. Corral Son of ‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-11-12 https://b‚Ä¶ # ‚Ñπ 80 more rows ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # bracero_clean |> # group_by(date_format, language) ``` ::: ## summarize() - `summarize()` is often used in tandem with the `group_by()` function to calculate summary statistic(s) for a group. - In this case we are grouping the `bracero_clean` dataframe by the values in the `language` column, and summarizing the number of interviews using the `n()` function in a new column called `n_interviews`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> group_by(language) |> summarize(n_interviews = n()) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 √ó 2 language n_interviews 1 eng 15 2 spa 75 ``` ::: ::: ## Other summarize functions - You can summarize values across groups using other functions, such as: - median() = median - mean() = average - sum() = sum ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> group_by(language) |> summarize(med_date = median(date_format)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 √ó 2 language med_date 1 eng 2003-04-03 2 spa 2003-06-30 ``` ::: ::: ## slice {.smaller} - `slice_` functions help select a subset of rows - slice_head(n = 5) will take the first five rows of the data - slice_tail(n = 5) will take the last five rows of the data - slice_min(x, n = 5) will take the five rows of data with the lowest values for column x. - slice_max(x, n = 5) will take the five rows of data with the highest values for column x. - slice_sample(n = 5) will select 5 random rows of data. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> slice_min(date_format, n = 3) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 √ó 6 interviewee subject description language date_format identifier 1 Heriberto Cort√©z Cort√©z Bracero "Biographical‚Ä¶ spa 2002-05-13 https://b‚Ä¶ 2 Homero L√≥pez Ortiz Bracero "Biographical‚Ä¶ spa 2002-05-31 https://b‚Ä¶ 3 Patricio Corrales Rojas Bracero "Biographical‚Ä¶ spa 2002-07-02 https://b‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: # Exercises Three and Four {.smaller} - See assignment! - Part 3: grouping data - Part 4: Listen to an interview from the [Bracero archive](https://braceroarchive.org/), and answer questions related your interview/course readings. ## Logistics - Tuesday: two readings on rural electrification in NC, one oral history - Kat leading centering activity :-) - Grading HW 01 and 02 will be done this weekend!

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
